fields.description: Clean up for object histories is performed per bucket. When a bucket has many objects it is not possible to process them all within the 30 second timeout. Objects are ordered for processing, so some objects in the bucket will be processed normally, but other objects will never have clean up performed.
fields.summary: S3 cleaning object histories for bucket with many objects times out

comments.body:
By comparison, the block storage async tasks do not have such timeouts.
The Quartz job runs every ObjectStorageSchedulerManager#BUCKET_REAPER_DEFAULT_SCHEDULE (60 seconds), so if we lengthen the BucketReaperTask#MAX_TASK_DURATION timeout above 60, the jobs may pile up. 
Since this is just cleanup of metadata, it's not very important to run often. For simplicity given the state of Eucalyptus now, what if we raised the timeout to 120 minutes, and the schedule to 240 minutes? Then the task will have a very high probability of finishing (we could test the limits), and will run at most 2 hours out of every 4.

I haven't looked at the impact, but I would guess we'd want BucketReaperTask#resolveBucketState to run more frequently (i.e. every few minutes) to handle bucket creation and deletion work. Perhaps we could split out the object history cleanup to another scheduled job with timing as you propose (if bucket state handling would otherwise be impacted)

For 4.4.2, we could consider adding an (occasional) warning log message when cleanup does not complete as an alternative to making more invasive changes. Then if this issue occurs it will be visible and action can be take to address it (remove objects if they are not needed, etc)
[~lincoln.thomas], how about we go with logging a message when this issue is hit so we can identify when we may need to do some manual clean up.

Do we really want to ask the user to delete objects because our cleanup routine is not completing within our arbitrary timeout period?

I think a good compromise including your feedbacks (thanks!) is:

# During the bucket reaper task, we can resolveBucketState for all buckets first (which should be fast, even with lots of buckets, regardless of number of objects), then cleanObjectHistoriesInBucket for as much time as remains in the timeout. So the history cleanup won't block bucket state cleanup.
# Adding the warning as suggested (identifying the bucket and object it was on, when it was interrupted), 
# Raising the timeout to 10 minutes, running every 20 minutes. That gives it 20x the time to clean up. 

Outside this task: A bucket creation waits for 60 seconds before giving up anyway, independently of this task. A bucket deletion normally happens right away, so users should rarely have to wait for this reaper to run before seeing a bucket as deleted; having to clean this up usually indicates a failed deletion. So extending the period for resolveBucketState doesn't seem too bad, since normal operation isn't blocked by this task.

We can do any or all of the above.

This is a small change set, see:
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/pull/109
(Certain log messages temporarily raised from Trace to Info for testing only, or newly added as Info and will become Trace)

[~lincoln.thomas], the thinking was that even extending the timeout would not allow cleanup to complete in the case of millions of objects. [~sjones], what do you think of [~lincoln.thomas]'s suggestion?

I think it is fine to suggest deleting objects for better clean up performance. In some cases there could be objects stored that are not needed and in this case deleting them is reasonable. I agree it is not reasonable to expect all users to delete objects to address this issue.

Performing resolveBucketState first for all buckets sounds good. The only potential issue is that if you have many buckets this would mean you would never perform cleanObjectHistoriesInBucket for any buckets. We might want to log a specific warning if this timeout during resolveBucketState processing occurs. Ideally we would use a random bucket order here to mitigate any potential timeout issues. I would not log processing each bucket at INFO level as there could be many buckets.

I don't know how many objects are processed currently (30 second timeout) or how many would be processed with a 10 minute timeout. We should test to ensure that our changes address the issue as it is not clear what the benefit is of making those changes otherwise. If we log how many objects have been processed when a timeout occurs then this should be easy to evaluate.

I would not change the default timing for the task in 4.4.2 if it causes any behavioural differences (I'm not aware of any) or if it does not address the issue.

Testing results overnight with the changed code:
* 1,000 buckets, 1 object in each bucket (1,000 objects), resolveBucketState took <1 second, and cleanObjectHistoriesInBucket took 6 seconds.
* 10,000 buckets, and 5 objects per bucket (50,000 objects), resolveBucketState still took <1 second, and cleanObjectHistoriesInBucket took 2 min 54 sec.
(Note the default limit is 100 buckets per account. I raised euctl objectstorage.max_buckets_per_account to allow 10,000 in one account for testing.)

This is why I didn't randomize resolveBucketState, since it should take almost no time relative to cleaning object histories. 

However, if cleanObjectHistoriesInBucket had the 30-sec timeout, only 17% of the objects would be cleaned (8k objects in 30 sec), whereas they all completed in 3 minutes. The suggested 10 minute timeout would allow 172k objects to be cleaned, more chance of completing at least one bucket of lots of objects in one timeout which is the issue here. 
I'm re-testing with lots of objects in one bucket to see how long that takes, which is the original issue here (not completing the objects in just one bucket within the timeout).

Yes, I will add Warnings upon timeout, both within resolveBucketState and cleanObjectHistoriesInBucket.

Good idea "log how many objects have been processed when a timeout occurs", will add that.

(The messaging at INFO is for testing only and will be lowered per my earlier comment.)
[~lincoln.thomas], for reference approximate scale targets are 50K buckets and 10M objects (not evenly distributed, 100,000 objects per bucket is the target)
[~lincoln.thomas], feel free to assign to me and give me the current status and I can move this issue along.

Thanks for the target numbers @jones. Committed now.

h3. Test results:

h4. 1st deployment
Same deployment used in earlier test results here, 8GB machines, CLC / UFS / Walrus all on separate nodes: (VPC)

Uploaded 855,000 objects to one "bigbucket" with "aws s3 sync" in 19.4 hours.

Still resolved all buckets states in <1 sec

Using a hour timeout for testing, cleaning object records (mostly from bigbucket) timed out after cleaning 359,000 objects, those from bigbucket took 58m 49s = 101 obj/sec
So, orig 30 sec at avg 200 obj/s means you can have 6,000 objs in one bucket max (with not much in other buckets) if you want it to complete.
10 min = 120,000 objs
15 min = 180,000 objs

h4. 2nd deployment:

Built new quick launch w/ my branch, Edge, 64GB RAM machines, default topology with CLC and UFS+Walrus nodes, concise regression passed.

Created 50,000 buckets, 2 obj in each, and 1 bigbucket with 100,000 objects. The bigbucket finished populating (with aws sync) before object finished populating in the other buckets.

After 3,700 buckets populated (2 obj each) so far, so 7% of the existing 50,000 buckets having 2 objects, but with fully populated bigbucket, cleaning took 4.8 min to complete. (buckets still resolved in <1 sec).
4.8m = 288s = 347 obj/s, 3.5x the other deployment. (topology differences?)

Added another 100,000 objs to bigbucket. Stopped populating the other 50,000 buckets after 35,500 populated overnight. So 70% of them had 2 objs, the other 30% had zero. Total 135,500 objects.

Finished resolving bucket states in <2 sec.
Finished cleanups after 15 minutes (timed out). 
Cleaned 200,000 objects in bigbucket in 10.3m = 323 obj/s, so a linear time increase with more objects. It timed out cleaning the other 50,000 buckets, but it had cleaned them 

So, depending on your topology, a 15min timeout would allow at least a 180,000-object bucket to complete (~300,000 on the faster topology), which meets the 100,000 object target desired. This is also in the presence of the target 50,000 buckets, with 0-2 objects in each (it timed out doing the other buckets).

I got the desired Warnings when it timed out.
I've committed the code with the 15 minute timeout, running every 30 minutes. Feel free to change it if desired.

_Note: The bucket that it warns about, when it times out, may not be the bucket that has the most objects. For example, I saw this once:_

{noformat}
Fri Jul 21 11:55:05 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-3] Timed out while cleaning up object records in bucket uuid 901c9dac-03d2-4ca7-a504-039738223116, name buckettest34500 after processing 2 objects.
Fri Jul 21 11:55:05 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-3] Timed out while cleaning up object records after processing 41473 buckets.
Fri Jul 21 11:55:05 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-3] Timed out while cleaning up object records after processing 41473 buckets.
{noformat}

(The double Warning is because of multiple places in the code it could be logged, depending on variable checks vs. interrupted threads, maybe could be optimized but not a big deal IMHO)
The bigbucket finished within the timeout, but it timed out while doing all the other 50,000 buckets. This one only had 2 objects in it. But it's more likely that a bucket with lots of objects will be the one it shows. Also, buckets are processed randomly, so if it consistently times out, you'll see Warnings after each run, more likely being the ones with larger numbers of objects, so you can let it run to see what buckets pop up.

Closed pull request https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/pull/109 (temporary, several commits for testing) and opened and merged new squashed pull request https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/pull/110

The changes currently in QA for this issue look good to me overall. I think further changes are are required for the timing aspect.

Currently there are two different settings for the timing of this cleanup task. The first is the scheduler configuration for the task interval for which the default value is in the code, but the value actually used is from the database. The second setting is the timeout configured in the task (code) itself. These settings have to be changed together to get reasonable behaviour and currently on upgrade I think you would get new settings for the task timeout, but not for the scheduler which (I assume) would mean you could end up with 15 concurrently running cleanup tasks.

The timing of the task is reverted to very minute and and all object storage gateway tasks are updated so that they do not run concurrently. A system property is added that can be used to disable the timeout on a selected object storage gateway:

{code}
-Dcom.eucalyptus.objectstorage.bucketReaperTimeout=false
{code}

when this is set the task will process all objects in a bucket without respecting any timeout. While the task is running no other instances of this task will start. 

When the timeout is enabled there can be logging each hour warning if the task did not complete (as noted in previous comment):

{code}
Thu Jul 27 13:47:17 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-1] Timed out while cleaning up object records in bucket uuid 92198a60-a26b-4b43-ac00-199b533e4219, name sjones after processing 6000 objects.
Thu Jul 27 13:47:17 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-1] Timed out while cleaning up object records after processing 4 buckets.
Thu Jul 27 14:00:17 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-3] Timed out while cleaning up object records in bucket uuid 92198a60-a26b-4b43-ac00-199b533e4219, name sjones after processing 6000 objects.
Thu Jul 27 14:00:17 2017  WARN [BucketReaperTask:QuartzScheduler_Worker-3] Timed out while cleaning up object records after processing 5 buckets.
(END)
{code}

from the timestamps you can see this is logged at 13:47 on service restart and then again at 14:00. You would see similar logging at 15:00, etc. The timeout is determined from the task schedule, so the time of the next run minus 30 seconds. This means that you could change the task interval to 1 hour (for example) by updating the db schedule, this is not recommended, particularly if you have more than one object storage gateway.

With the settings reverted there should be no user visible functionality change on upgraded systems other than logging if a timeout occurs and that bucket state is processed first on each task run.
LGTM. Good to have the property to let it run as long as it takes. Consolidating the timeout to one value you can change in the database (if needed) is helpful too! Thanks [~sjones]

For testing:

Create a bucket with 100,000 objects. I did it by creating 100,000 files on the UFS node, and uploading them to s3 by:

{noformat}
mkdir ~/files
cd ~/files
time for x in $(seq 1 100000); do touch file-$x; done
aws --endpoint http://s3.g-19-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/ s3 mb s3://bigbucket
time aws --endpoint http://s3.g-19-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/ s3 sync --dryrun . s3://bigbucket
time aws --endpoint http://s3.g-19-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/ s3 sync . s3://bigbucket
{noformat}

Might take 5-10 minutes to create all the objects, and maybe 2 hours to upload them all to s3. The --dryrun is a sanity check which you can Ctrl-C after it start off well.

Within 1 hour, you should start to see the WARN messages in cloud-debug.log as shown above, with "...Timed out while cleaning up object records..."

Stop the cloud process on the UFS (systemctl stop eucalyptus-cloud), and add the following to CLOUD_OPTS in /etc/eucalyptus/eucalyptus.conf:

{noformat}
-Dcom.eucalyptus.objectstorage.bucketReaperTimeout=false
{noformat}

Restart the cloud. The Warnings should go away.

Verified, the warning disappeared after restarted the eucalyptus-cloud process on the UFS.

*Installed Packages*
{code}
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.4.2
Release     : 0.25939.65.20170804git4e99b23.el7
Size        : 243 k
Repo        : installed
{code}
